sourceModules.title: Principles and Application of Tactical Field Care

notes: Question types supported: single, multi, multi_not, order, match, true_false.
true_false questions store answer as boolean (true/false).
order questions store answer as ordered list of step keys.

questions.prompt: Which TCCC tier does the Combat Lifesaver (CLS) fall under?
questions.note: CLS is TCCC Tier 2. Source: CLS 01

questions.prompt: TCCC focuses on treating all injuries equally, regardless of their impact on survivability.
questions.note: TCCC prioritizes preventable causes of death. Source: CLS 01

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which are listed preventable causes of death addressed by TCCC?
options: Bleeding from arm and leg injuries
Noncompressible abdominal bleeding (e.g., gunshot wound to abdomen)
questions.note: These are listed under TCCC importance / preventable death causes. Source: CLS 01

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT one of the three goals of TCCC?
options: Evacuate the casualty as soon as possible
questions.note: The three goals are treat casualty, prevent additional casualties, complete mission. Source: CLS 01

questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of a tourniquet in CLS care?
questions.note: Tourniquet is a device to stop massive bleeding. Source: CLS 02

questions.prompt: The Combat Wound Medication Pack (CWMP) should be used for all injuries, including minor cuts and abrasions.
questions.note: CWMP is for traumatic and penetrating injuries only. Source: CLS 02/05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which items are included in the medical equipment content overview for CLS training?
questions.note: These items appear across equipment overview slides. Source: CLS 02

questions.prompt: When rendering aid to a casualty, which supplies should be used first?
options: Supplies from the nearest aid station
questions.note: Always use the casualty’s JFAK first. Source: CLS 01/02/04

questions.prompt: What is the DD Form 1380 (TCCC Card) used for?
options: Documenting all assessment and treatment before evacuation or handoff
questions.note: DD Form 1380 is the DoD-approved standard for documenting assessment/treatment. Source: CLS 02/04/05

questions.prompt: A MEDEVAC request is divided into how many lines of information?
questions.note: MEDEVAC request uses a 9-line format. Source: CLS 02/01/05

questions.prompt: Which action takes priority during Care Under Fire (CUF)?
options: Gain fire superiority / suppress hostile fire
questions.note: CUF priorities emphasize suppression of hostile fire and tactical safety. Source: CLS 01/03

questions.prompt: A rescuer should immediately move toward a casualty even if hostile fire is ongoing.
questions.note: Do not attempt rescue until hostile fire is suppressed / fire superiority gained. Source: CLS 01/03

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which are signs of life-threatening bleeding?
options: Traumatic amputation of an arm or leg
Pulsatile (pulsing) or steady bleeding from a wound
Bright red blood pooling on the ground
questions.note: Listed signs used to identify life-threatening bleeding. Source: CLS 03/05

questions.prompt: In Care Under Fire movements, spinal injuries are not a primary concern compared to getting the casualty to cover.
questions.note: CUF movement emphasizes speed and cover; spinal concerns are deprioritized during CUF movement. Source: CLS 03

questions.prompt: During CUF, where should a tourniquet be placed for life-threatening bleeding?
options: High and tight above the wound
questions.note: CUF guidance uses 'high and tight' application. Source: CLS 01/03

questions.prompt: When helping a buddy, you should use your own tourniquet before checking the casualty’s JFAK.
questions.note: Use the casualty’s JFAK first; do not use your own tourniquet before the casualty’s. Source: CLS 03

questions.prompt: How quickly can a casualty bleed to death from a major artery injury (as taught in CUF materials)?
questions.note: CUF materials emphasize catastrophic hemorrhage can kill in as little as 3 minutes. Source: CLS 03/05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that do NOT apply: Which actions are NOT consistent with CUF principles?
options: Approach a casualty while they are inside a kill zone
Suppress hostile fire to gain fire superiority
Direct casualty to apply self-aid and move to cover (if able)
Conduct a full head-to-toe exam before moving the casualty
questions.note: Do not approach in kill zone; CUF is not the phase for a full deliberate assessment. Source: CLS 03/01

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which one-person drag/carry methods are referenced in CUF training materials?
questions.note: These are listed one-person methods; fireman’s carry is not listed in the referenced snippet. Source: CLS 03

questions.prompt: Tactical Field Care (TFC) is rendered when the casualty and the person rendering care are no longer under effective enemy fire or threat.
questions.note: TFC begins when not under effective enemy fire or threat. Source: CLS 04

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which actions support security and safety during Tactical Field Care?
options: Establish a security perimeter per SOP/battle drills
Mix weapons and radios with shock or narcotics
questions.note: Weapons/radios do not mix well with shock or narcotics; security is a priority. Source: CLS 04

questions.prompt: Which injury is the #1 priority when triaging multiple casualties in TFC guidance?
questions.note: Triage prioritization lists massive bleeding as #1. Source: CLS 04

questions.prompt: What does the acronym MIST stand for (as used for casualty handoff/communication)?
options: Mechanism of injury, Injuries, Symptoms, Treatment
questions.note: MIST: Mechanism, Injuries, Symptoms, Treatment. Source: CLS 04/05/01

questions.prompt: During TFC, the tactical situation could change back to Care Under Fire (CUF) at any time.
questions.note: TFC does not mean danger is over; it can revert to CUF. Source: CLS 04

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which principles are stated for casualty removal/extraction?
options: The second principle of MARCH still applies; initiate lifesaving measures if possible
Extraction is identical across all missions and vehicles
Always delay tourniquet application until after extraction
questions.note: Extraction varies; safety, MARCH still applies, training. Source: CLS 04

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: What does MARCH PAWS stand for?
questions.note: MARCH during life-threatening; PAWS after. Source: CLS 05/04/01

questions.prompt: A Tactical Trauma Assessment (TTA) uses which mnemonic to prioritize care?
questions.note: TTA prioritization uses MARCH PAWS. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Whenever possible, the responder should don latex-free gloves as a precaution during a Tactical Trauma Assessment.
questions.note: Body Substance Isolation (BSI) guidance. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: A casualty blood sweep should include checking which areas?
questions.note: Blood sweep is rapid head-to-toe check for unrecognized life-threatening bleeding. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which are signs and symptoms of shock listed in the TTA module?
options: Weak or absent radial pulses (or low blood pressure)
questions.note: These indicators are listed as shock signs/symptoms. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which statements about hypothermia prevention are taught in TTA materials?
options: Hypothermia is easier to prevent than to treat
Begin hypothermia prevention as soon as possible
Decreased body temperature interferes with blood clotting and increases bleeding risk
Blood loss can significantly drop body temperature even in hot weather
Hypothermia is only an issue in cold environments
questions.note: Hypothermia prevention must begin early and applies even in hot environments. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: If a penetrating eye injury is suspected, you should cover both eyes even if only one eye is injured.
questions.note: Do not cover both eyes unless both are injured. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which CWMP components and notes are stated in the TTA module?
options: CWMP is found in the JFAK
Document all medications administered (and time given) on DD Form 1380
Meloxicam can give significant pain relief and will not alter the casualty’s mental status
CWMP contains an oral antibiotic medication (Moxifloxacin)
Acetaminophen is used for pain management
questions.note: CWMP items and documentation guidance are listed. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: After dressing known wounds, bandages should be assessed for which warning signs?
questions.note: If warning signs exist, bandage may be too tight; loosen while controlling bleeding. Source: CLS 05

questions.prompt: Put these Care Under Fire actions in the correct order (general sequence).
questions.hint: Drag to reorder from first → last.

steps.label: Gain fire superiority / suppress hostile fire
Apply tourniquet to control life-threatening bleeding

questions.note: CUF emphasizes fire superiority and controlling life-threatening bleeding before movement when feasible. Source: CLS 01/03

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which are listed as key factors influencing TCCC?
options: Delays in reaching higher levels of care
Level of first responder training and experience
questions.note: Key factors influencing TCCC are listed on the 'Key Factors' slide.

questions.prompt: Put the three phases of TCCC in the correct order.
questions.hint: Drag to reorder from first → last.
questions.note: TCCC has three phases: CUF → TFC → TACEVAC.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: In a Care Under Fire situation, what must the CLS do according to the roles/responsibilities slide?
options: Respond to suppression of hostile fire to minimize risk of injury
Minimize additional injury to previously injured service members
Perform a full head-to-toe trauma assessment before moving the casualty
Maintain security and situational awareness while tending to casualties (TFC responsibility)
questions.note: The slide lists CUF-specific responsibilities.
questions.source: CLS 01.pdf (Roles and responsibilities of the Combat Lifesaver)

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: In Tactical Field Care, what must CLS service members do according to the roles/responsibilities slide?
questions.note: The TFC responsibilities are listed on the roles/responsibilities slide.
questions.source: CLS 01.pdf (Roles and responsibilities of the Combat Lifesaver)

questions.prompt: Role 1 care is also referred to as unit-level medical care or self-aid, buddy aid, combat lifesaver, and/or medic care.
questions.note: Role 1 care synonyms are explicitly listed.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Role 1 care includes which of the following?
options: Treatment for disease and non-battle injury (DNBI)
Treatment for degradation of functional capability from factors not attributed to enemy action
questions.note: Role 1 scope is described in the Role 1 care slide text.

questions.prompt: Hemostatic gauze is described as:
options: Gauze rolls used to stop major life-threatening bleeding
A device used to treat airway obstruction
A blanket used to prevent hypothermia
A rigid shield used to protect an injured eye
questions.note: Hemostatic gauze purpose is defined in the equipment overview.

questions.prompt: An NPA (nasopharyngeal airway) is described as:
options: A nonsterile, rubber tube-shaped device inserted into a casualty’s nostril
A needle inserted into the chest to treat tension pneumothorax
An adhesive dressing used to seal penetrating chest wounds
A medication pack used only for traumatic injuries
questions.note: NPA description appears in the equipment overview.

questions.prompt: A vented chest seal is used for:
options: Treating penetrating wounds to the chest
questions.note: Vented chest seal purpose appears in the equipment overview.

questions.prompt: The NDC 10–14 gauge 3.25" needle catheter is described as a device used to:
options: Seal an open chest wound without venting
questions.note: Needle catheter purpose appears in the equipment overview.

questions.prompt: MACE2 is used for identifying possible traumatic brain injury (TBI).
questions.note: MACE2 purpose is stated under Documentation.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which medications are listed as components of the Combat Wound Medication Pack (CWMP) in the equipment overview?
questions.note: CWMP contents are listed in the overview slide.

questions.prompt: During Care Under Fire, you should NOT approach a casualty while the casualty is inside of a kill zone.
questions.note: Kill zone warning is explicitly stated under CUF principles.

questions.prompt: If a casualty is unable to move to cover, when should you go to them to aid in movement (when tactically feasible)?
options: Only after fire has been suppressed and fire superiority has been gained
Only after a full MARCH PAWS assessment is completed
questions.note: The slide states to go to them when fire is suppressed and fire superiority gained.
questions.source: CLS 03.pdf (If casualty is unable to move)

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: If a casualty is unable to move to cover, what items are suggested to aid movement?
questions.note: Rope and dragging straps are explicitly listed examples.

questions.prompt: When moving casualties under fire, spinal injuries are not to be a concern during Care Under Fire movements.
questions.note: Stated explicitly in the casualty movement guidance section.

questions.prompt: Which one-person carry method should be used for a conscious casualty only?
questions.note: Support carry is listed for conscious casualty only.

questions.prompt: Which statement best describes an advantage of the neck drag during CUF?
options: It limits the casualty and rescuer from exposure to enemy fire
It requires no training and is risk-free
It is used only for vehicle extraction
It is the best method for stairs
questions.note: Neck drag advantage is explicitly described.

questions.prompt: Cradle-drop drag is described as effective for:
options: Moving a casualty up or down stairs/steps or short distances
questions.note: Cradle-drop drag use-case is stated in the drag/carry list.

questions.prompt: Fore and aft carry exposes:
options: Two rescuers to hostile fire instead of one
Only the casualty to hostile fire
Only one rescuer to hostile fire
questions.note: Fore and aft carry disadvantage is stated explicitly.

questions.prompt: Extractions will vary based on the mission and vehicles located in your Area of Responsibility (AOR).
questions.note: Extraction variability is stated explicitly.

questions.prompt: In casualty removal/extraction principles, what is stated as the first principle?
questions.note: The slide states: 'The first principle is safety.'

questions.prompt: In casualty removal/extraction principles, the second principle states that:
options: MARCH still applies; initiate lifesaving measures like a tourniquet before extraction if possible
Only move casualties after MEDEVAC arrives
Do not treat until extraction is complete
questions.note: The slide states MARCH still applies and suggests initiating lifesaving measures before extraction if possible.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: When communicating with a casualty in TFC, what actions are listed?
options: Explain care each step of the way
Ignore the casualty to maintain tempo
questions.note: Communication actions are listed on the communication slide.

questions.prompt: All assessment and medical care (including interventions and medications) should be documented on the DD Form 1380.
questions.note: Documentation requirement is explicit.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which items are included in the MIST report?
questions.note: MIST components are listed under MEDEVAC communication.

questions.prompt: A MIST report may change as the casualty status and interventions performed change.
questions.note: Stated explicitly in the hand-off guidance.

questions.prompt: If you suspect a casualty has suffered a neck or spinal injury, which airway-opening maneuver should you use?
questions.note: Jaw thrust is recommended when neck/spinal injury suspected.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which airway-opening maneuvers are listed for a casualty without an airway obstruction?
questions.note: Opening the airway maneuvers listed include head-tilt chin lift and jaw thrust.

questions.prompt: For an unconscious casualty not in shock, what position is recommended for airway management?
questions.note: The slide states to place an unconscious casualty not in shock into the recovery position.

questions.prompt: Casualties with severe facial trauma can often protect their own airways by:
options: Having the responder perform a blind finger sweep
questions.note: Severe facial trauma airway guidance is explicitly stated.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: When assessing for life-threatening chest injury, what should the responder expose the chest to assess for?
questions.note: Chest injury assessment indicators are listed on the respiration assessment slide.

questions.prompt: If penetrating trauma is found or identified during chest assessment, what is the indicated action?
options: Apply a chest seal (vented, if available)
Apply a tourniquet to the neck
Give CWMP immediately regardless of injury
questions.note: Penetrating chest trauma guidance states to apply a chest seal (vented if available).

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Under 'Reassess Treatments' in circulation, what should be reassessed?
questions.note: Reassess airway, respirations, and massive hemorrhage treatments.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which are listed signs and symptoms of shock?
options: Weak or absent radial pulses (or low blood pressure)
questions.note: Shock signs/symptoms list appears on the 'General indicator of shock' slide.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which statements about hypothermia prevention are listed?
options: Hypothermia is much easier to prevent than to treat
Begin hypothermia prevention as soon as possible
Decreased body temperature interferes with blood clotting and increases bleeding risk
Blood loss can cause a significant drop in body temperature even in hot weather
Hypothermia is only an issue in cold environments
questions.note: Hypothermia prevention guidance emphasizes early prevention and hot-environment relevance.

questions.prompt: If a penetrating eye injury is suspected, do not cover both eyes unless both eyes are injured.
questions.note: Eye injury guidance explicitly states this rule.

questions.prompt: TCCC training applies only to combat environments and does not apply to noncombat settings.
questions.note: TCCC applies to both combat and noncombat environments.

questions.prompt: Which publication standardizes combat casualty care for all Service members?
questions.note: DoDI 1322.24 mandates standardized combat casualty care.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that do NOT apply: Which actions are NOT goals of TCCC?
options: Maximize comfort regardless of tactical risk
questions.note: Goals are limited to three; zero injury and comfort maximization are not listed.

questions.prompt: Expired medical equipment may be deployed if it appears undamaged.
questions.note: Expired or unsealed equipment must be replaced.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: When inspecting a JFAK or CLS bag, what should be checked?
options: That all required equipment is present
That equipment has been previously used in training
questions.note: Used, missing, or expired equipment must be replaced.

questions.prompt: Which item provides domed protection for eye injuries WITHOUT applying pressure?
questions.note: Rigid eye shield protects eye injuries without pressure.

questions.prompt: In Care Under Fire, controlling life-threatening bleeding may take priority over casualty movement when tactically feasible.
questions.note: Bleeding control may occur before movement when possible.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that do NOT apply: Which actions should NOT be performed during Care Under Fire?
options: Direct casualty to self-aid and move
questions.note: Deliberate assessments are not performed during CUF.

questions.prompt: Which carry method exposes two rescuers to hostile fire?
questions.note: Fore and aft carry exposes two rescuers.

questions.prompt: Limited medical supplies are a consideration during Tactical Field Care.
questions.note: Medical supplies are limited to what is carried into the field.

questions.prompt: What should be done with weapons and radios when a casualty has altered mental status?
options: Secure them to prevent accidental harm
questions.note: Weapons and communications must be secured.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which factors must be communicated to leadership during TFC?
questions.note: Leadership communication must include accurate casualty data.

questions.prompt: A casualty with severe injuries can bleed to death in as little as three minutes.
questions.note: This warning is emphasized during hemorrhage instruction.

questions.prompt: During a casualty blood sweep, which motion is recommended for the chest and abdomen?
questions.note: Chest and abdomen are checked using a raking motion.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that do NOT apply: Which are NOT signs of shock?
questions.note: A strong bounding pulse is not a shock indicator.

questions.prompt: Why must hypothermia prevention begin as soon as possible?
options: It interferes with blood clotting and increases bleeding risk if untreated
It replaces the need for hemorrhage control
questions.note: Hypothermia worsens bleeding and clotting.

questions.prompt: Blind finger sweeps are recommended when blood or foreign objects are visible in the airway.
questions.note: Blind finger sweeps are specifically discouraged.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: You are in Care Under Fire. A teammate is down in an exposed area and you can still hear incoming rounds. The casualty is yelling and appears able to move. What is your best immediate action?
options: Move immediately to the casualty and begin a head-to-toe assessment
Direct the casualty to remain engaged, apply self-aid, and move to cover if able
Stop firing and run to drag the casualty out as quickly as possible
Begin Tactical Field Care interventions where they are
questions.rationale: CUF priorities emphasize return fire/take cover, gaining/maintaining fire superiority, and directing the casualty to self-aid and move to cover if able. Approaching while the area is still a kill zone is specifically discouraged.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: During Care Under Fire, you see bright red blood pooling near a casualty’s leg and clothing rapidly soaking with blood. The casualty cannot move. What action aligns best with CUF guidance?
options: Apply a tourniquet high and tight above the wound and then move the casualty based on the tactical situation
Perform airway maneuvers first because breathing is always first priority
Delay hemorrhage control until you reach Tactical Field Care
Loosen any tourniquet every few minutes to allow blood flow
questions.rationale: CUF emphasizes controlling life-threatening bleeding with a tourniquet (‘high and tight’) and moving the casualty out of the kill zone if they are unable to move. Delaying hemorrhage control can be fatal.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In Tactical Field Care, a casualty has facial trauma and is conscious but struggling to breathe. What positioning guidance best fits the airway management slides?
options: Force them flat on their back to keep the spine straight
Assist them to sit up and lean forward if that allows easier breathing
Immediately perform a blind finger sweep to clear the airway
Place them in recovery position regardless of shock status
questions.rationale: Conscious casualties should be assisted into a position that allows them to breathe easily. Severe facial trauma casualties can often protect their airway by sitting up and leaning forward. Blind finger sweeps are discouraged.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: An unconscious casualty is found in Tactical Field Care. You suspect a neck/spinal injury. There is no visible airway obstruction. Which airway maneuver is most appropriate?
questions.rationale: When neck or spinal injury is suspected, the jaw thrust method is recommended. Blind finger sweeps are specifically warned against.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In Tactical Field Care, a casualty has a penetrating wound to the chest. You expose the chest and see signs consistent with penetrating trauma. Select ALL actions that best align with the respiration assessment guidance.
options: Expose the chest to assess for chest injury indicators
Apply a chest seal (vented, if available) when penetrating trauma is identified
Ignore bruising/contusions because only gunshot wounds matter
Treat tension pneumothorax with a tourniquet
Continue to reassess respirations as part of MARCH
questions.rationale: Respiration assessment guidance lists exposing the chest and applying a chest seal (vented if available) for penetrating trauma. The module also emphasizes reassessment as you proceed through MARCH.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: During assessment, the casualty is pale/clammy, breathing rapidly, and has altered mental status. Select ALL findings that match the module’s shock indicators.
questions.rationale: The shock slide lists altered mental status, rapid breathing, sweaty cool clammy skin, and excess thirst among indicators. A strong bounding radial pulse is not presented as a shock indicator.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: You are treating a casualty in warm weather after significant blood loss. A teammate says hypothermia prevention isn’t necessary because it’s hot. What is the best response based on the module?
options: Agree — hypothermia prevention is only for cold environments
Disagree — blood loss can significantly drop body temperature even in hot weather; begin prevention early
Agree — hypothermia only matters after evacuation
Disagree — but only start prevention if the casualty is shivering
questions.rationale: The module states hypothermia is easier to prevent than treat and should begin as soon as possible. It also notes blood loss can cause significant temperature drop even in hot weather.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: You are preparing to extract a casualty from a vehicle/platform in Tactical Field Care. Which principle is stated as the FIRST priority in extraction guidance?
questions.rationale: Extraction principles explicitly state safety is the first principle and is critical. Other considerations follow.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: During Tactical Field Care, you are providing care and coordinating evacuation. Select ALL actions that align with the communication/documentation guidance.
options: Communicate evacuation requirements to tactical leadership immediately
Keep the casualty’s DD Form 1380 up to date
Relay a MIST report (Mechanism, Injuries, Symptoms, Treatment)
Avoid documenting medications to save time
Only communicate once; do not update leadership as care changes
questions.rationale: Guidance emphasizes timely comms to leadership for evac requirements, keeping DD Form 1380 current, and using the MIST report. Leadership should be updated as status/interventions change.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In Care Under Fire, you and a casualty reach cover. The casualty’s leg is badly bleeding, and their JFAK is accessible. What action best follows CLS guidance?
options: Apply a tourniquet high and tight using the casualty’s JFAK, then reassess the tactical situation
Wait until Tactical Field Care to control the bleeding
Use your own med bag supplies first to preserve the casualty’s kit
Loosen the tourniquet every few minutes to restore circulation
questions.rationale: CLS guidance stresses rapid hemorrhage control in CUF, using a high-and-tight tourniquet, and prioritizing the casualty’s JFAK to preserve your supplies for additional casualties.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: You are moving a casualty toward a casualty collection point in Tactical Field Care. Select ALL actions that align with extraction principles and continued care.
options: Maintain safety of the team and casualty throughout movement
Stop all reassessments once movement starts
Use the casualty’s JFAK before drawing on your own supplies
Prioritize speed even if it increases exposure to hazards
questions.rationale: Extraction guidance emphasizes safety as the first priority, continuing MARCH-based reassessment, and using the casualty’s JFAK first when possible. Speed is important but never replaces safety.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: A casualty shows signs of shock after bleeding is controlled. Which action best reflects immediate CLS care?
options: Prevent hypothermia, monitor closely, and prepare for evacuation
Force large amounts of oral fluids immediately
Place the casualty prone to improve circulation
Delay care until all documentation is complete
questions.rationale: Shock management includes preventing hypothermia early, monitoring status, and preparing for evacuation. Forcing oral fluids is not always appropriate, and delaying care is unsafe.

questions.prompt: Which type of bleeding is typically bright red and spurting, and may be life-threatening?
questions.rationale: Module 06 describes arterial bleeding as bright red and spurting; it is urgent and often difficult to control.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Which findings suggest life-threatening hemorrhage?
options: Pulsatile (pulsing) or steady bleeding from the wound
Bright red blood pooling on the ground
Minor oozing from a superficial scrape
questions.rationale: Module 06 lists pooling, soaked clothes, ineffective bandages, pulsatile/steady bleeding, and amputations as signs of severe hemorrhage.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Characteristics of non-life-threatening bleeding include:
options: No pulsatile or steady bleeding from the wound
No blood pooling on the ground
Bandages effective and not steadily soaking through
Partial or complete traumatic limb amputation
questions.rationale: Module 06 defines non-life-threatening bleeds by absence of pooling, soaked clothes, arterial/venous patterns, and absence of amputation.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Tools for life-threatening hemorrhage control include:
questions.rationale: Module 06 lists these tools explicitly as hemorrhage control tools.

questions.prompt: Direct pressure can be used as a temporary measure until a tourniquet or dressing is in place.
questions.rationale: Module 06 states direct pressure can and should be used temporarily until definitive control is applied.

questions.prompt: Which tourniquet should be used as the FIRST option when available?
options: The responder’s tourniquet from their own JFAK
The casualty’s tourniquet from the casualty’s own JFAK
questions.rationale: Module 06 states the first option is the casualty’s TQ from their own JFAK.

questions.prompt: In Tactical Field Care (TFC), where should a deliberate tourniquet be applied?
options: Over clothing, 6 inches above the wound
Directly on the skin, 2–3 inches above the wound
questions.rationale: Module 06 states deliberate TQs in TFC are applied 2–3 inches above the wound directly on the skin.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Tourniquet effectiveness checks include:
options: No distal pulse below the tourniquet
Pulse becomes stronger below the tourniquet
Tourniquet is placed over a joint
questions.rationale: Module 06 states effectiveness is confirmed by bleeding stopped and no distal pulse.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that do NOT apply: Which are tourniquet pitfalls/mistakes?
options: Not pulling all slack out before tightening
Not making it tight enough to stop bleeding and eliminate distal pulse
Documenting tourniquet time during TFC (not CUF)
questions.rationale: Module 06 lists these as pitfalls; documenting time during TFC is correct guidance (not a mistake).

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Hemostatic dressing guidance includes:
options: It is safe and helps blood clot at the bleeding site
A JFAK contains one hemostatic dressing and one dry sterile gauze
Do NOT pack hemostatic dressing into the abdomen or chest
Hemostatic dressing is only used after evacuation
questions.rationale: Module 06 explicitly states these points and warns not to pack abdomen/chest.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: You identify a compressible junctional bleed that is not amenable to a limb tourniquet. Select ALL appropriate interventions based on Module 06.
options: Pack the wound with constant pressure at the source within 90 seconds
Hold direct pressure over the packed wound for at least 3 minutes
Pack hemostatic dressing into the abdomen if the wound is near the torso
questions.rationale: Module 06 supports hemostatic dressing for compressible junctional hemorrhage and emphasizes packing with constant pressure and holding pressure for at least 3 minutes; abdomen/chest packing is contraindicated.

questions.prompt: Airway obstruction on the battlefield is often due to:
questions.rationale: Module 07 states airway obstruction is often due to maxillofacial trauma.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Signs of an obstructed airway include:
options: Visible blood or foreign objects in the airway
Casualty indicates they can’t breathe properly
Strong, steady breathing with no distress
questions.rationale: Module 07 lists these as airway obstruction signs.

questions.prompt: If you see visible objects obstructing the airway, you should perform a blind finger sweep to clear it.
questions.rationale: Module 07 states to remove visible objects but do NOT perform a blind finger sweep.

questions.prompt: If you suspect a neck or spinal injury, which maneuver should you use to open the airway?
questions.rationale: Module 07 specifies jaw-thrust when spinal/neck injury is suspected.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Maintaining the airway/positioning guidance includes:
options: Let a casualty breathe in the position that works best for them (including sitting up)
Do not force airway procedures that make breathing more difficult if they can breathe on their own
Force all breathing casualties flat on their back
Severe facial injuries may protect their airway by sitting up and leaning forward
questions.rationale: Module 07 advises allowing comfortable breathing position and notes severe facial injuries often do best sitting up/leaning forward.

questions.prompt: For an unconscious casualty not in shock, what position is recommended?
questions.rationale: Module 07 states unconscious casualty not in shock should be placed into the recovery position.

questions.prompt: An NPA may be used on a conscious or unconscious casualty.
questions.rationale: Module 07 explicitly states an NPA may be used on conscious or unconscious casualties.

questions.prompt: You should NOT attempt to insert an NPA if clear fluid is coming from the nose or ears.
questions.rationale: Module 07 warns that clear fluid may be CSF indicating possible skull fracture—do not insert NPA.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In Tactical Field Care, a casualty is breathing on their own but is unconscious and has no obvious airway obstruction. What is the recommended next airway step?
options: Do nothing—airway is never a concern if breathing is present
questions.rationale: Module 07 states if the casualty is breathing on their own but unconscious/semi-conscious with no obstruction, airway management is achieved through an NPA.

questions.prompt: Respiratory distress means:
options: Difficulty breathing (rapid or abnormally slow), difficult to get air in or out
questions.rationale: Module 08 defines respiratory distress as difficulty breathing (rapid or abnormally slow).

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Signs/symptoms of an open pneumothorax (sucking chest wound) include:
options: Sucking or hissing sound when inhaling
Froth or bubbles around the injury
questions.rationale: Module 08 lists these findings for open pneumothorax/sucking chest wound.

questions.prompt: If you are not sure whether a wound penetrated the chest wall completely, treat it as an open chest wound.
questions.rationale: Module 08 explicitly instructs to treat as open chest wound if unsure.

questions.prompt: Recommended treatment for an open/sucking chest wound is:
options: Prompt application of a vented chest seal
A tourniquet placed over the chest
questions.rationale: Module 08 recommends prompt application of a vented chest seal; use nonvented if vented not available.

questions.prompt: If a vented chest seal is NOT available, what should be used?
questions.rationale: Module 08 states to use a nonvented chest seal if vented is not available.

questions.prompt: Vented chest seals allow air to escape out of the chest, while nonvented seals do not.
questions.rationale: Module 08 directly contrasts vented vs nonvented behavior.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: If a casualty with a chest seal worsens, you should suspect tension pneumothorax and:
options: Monitor closely and consider tension pneumothorax
Burp or temporarily remove the dressing
Apply a second chest seal over the first
questions.rationale: Module 08: worsening condition after seal suggests tension pneumothorax; treat by burping/temporarily removing dressing.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Signs/symptoms of progressive respiratory distress consistent with tension pneumothorax include:
options: Confusion/lightheadedness/agitation due to lack of oxygen
questions.rationale: Module 08 lists these signs for progressive respiratory distress/tension pneumothorax.

questions.prompt: You should put a needle decompression (NDC) through a chest seal if that is where the injury is located.
questions.rationale: Module 08 explicitly says DO NOT put NDC through a chest seal; use alternate site.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: If initial needle decompression does not improve the casualty, guidance includes:
options: Attempt a second NDC at the alternate recommended site
If symptoms recur after initial response, repeat NDC beside the original site
If no improvement after second NDC, proceed with circulation assessment/treatment per MARCH
Immediately discontinue MARCH and wait for evacuation
questions.rationale: Module 08 provides steps for unsuccessful or recurrent tension pneumothorax treatment.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In TFC, a casualty has a chest puncture wound with frothy bubbles and a hissing sound on inhalation. What is the best immediate treatment taught in this module?
options: Promptly apply a vented chest seal (or nonvented if vented is not available)
Apply a tourniquet high and tight around the chest
Wait to treat until symptoms worsen
questions.rationale: These findings match open pneumothorax/sucking chest wound; Module 08 recommends prompt application of a vented chest seal (or nonvented if vented unavailable).

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Pelvic fracture may be suspected after blunt force or blast with which findings?
options: Major lower limb amputation or near amputation
questions.rationale: Module 09 lists these physical signs suggesting pelvic fracture.

questions.prompt: If a pelvic fracture is suspected, the casualty will require advanced evaluation by medical personnel.
questions.rationale: Module 09 explicitly states suspected pelvic fractures require advanced evaluation.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Reassessment in hemorrhage control includes:
options: Reassess all previous and current applied tourniquets for tight/effective
If ineffective, apply a second tourniquet side-by-side
Reassess previous/current hemostatic dressings for effectiveness
Apply a tourniquet over clothing as standard practice
questions.rationale: Module 09 lists reassessment of tourniquets and hemostatic dressings; TQs in TFC should be on skin.

questions.prompt: CoTCCC-recommended tourniquets in Tactical Field Care are applied directly to the skin 2–3 inches above the bleeding site.
questions.rationale: Module 09 states TFC tourniquets are applied directly on skin 2–3 inches above bleeding site.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Indications for tourniquet replacement include:
options: Tourniquet applied too proximal (>3 inches above the wound)
questions.rationale: Module 09 lists these indications for tourniquet replacement.

questions.prompt: Order the steps for tourniquet conversion (as presented).
questions.hint: Drag to reorder from first → last.

steps.label: Pack wound and hold pressure for 3 minutes
Slowly release tourniquet over 1 minute, ensuring no rebleeding occurs
Document findings/treatments on DD Form 1380 (TCCC Card)

questions.rationale: Module 09 lists tourniquet conversion steps: pack + hold 3 min → pressure bandage → slowly release over 1 min with no rebleeding → document on DD1380.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Contraindications for tourniquet conversion include:
options: Inability to closely monitor for rebleeding
Tourniquet in place more than 6 hours (consider not converting)
questions.rationale: Module 09 lists shock, inability to monitor, and amputation as contraindications; also consider not converting if >6 hours.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In TFC, a casualty has a tourniquet placed over their uniform and bleeding is controlled. Evacuation to surgery is expected to take more than 2 hours. What is the best next action per this module?
options: Do nothing—if bleeding stopped, it never needs reassessment
Consider tourniquet replacement using a new tourniquet placed 2–3 inches proximal to the wound on skin, then slowly release original to check for rebleeding
Loosen the tourniquet every 10 minutes to restore circulation
questions.rationale: Module 09 indicates replacement is considered when TQ is over uniform and >2 hours to surgery; replacement involves a new TQ on skin and controlled release of the original while watching for rebleeding.

questions.prompt: Shock is best described as:
options: Too much oxygen delivery to tissues
Inadequate blood flow to body tissues leading to inadequate oxygen delivery
Only a psychological reaction to combat
questions.rationale: Module 10 defines shock as inadequate blood flow and inadequate oxygen delivery to cells/tissues.

questions.prompt: On the battlefield, assume shock is from severe blood loss (hemorrhagic shock).
questions.rationale: Module 10 states to assume hemorrhagic shock from severe blood loss in battlefield context.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: General indicators of shock include:
questions.rationale: Module 10 lists these as signs/symptoms of shock.

questions.prompt: The best TACTICAL indicators of shock (if no head injury) are:
options: Normal skin color and mild thirst
Decreased state of consciousness and/or abnormal, weak, absent radial pulse
questions.rationale: Module 10: best tactical indicators are decreased consciousness (if no head injury) and weak/absent radial pulse.

questions.prompt: If BOTH mental confusion and weak/absent radial pulse are present, the casualty has likely lost a significant amount of blood.
questions.rationale: Module 10 states if both indicators exist, significant blood loss has occurred.

questions.prompt: What is the most important action to prevent hemorrhagic shock?
options: Give fluids by mouth to everyone
questions.rationale: Module 10 emphasizes preventing shock by controlling bleeding and reassessing hemorrhage control measures.

questions.prompt: Assess for shock as soon as hemorrhage is controlled, the airway is open, and respirations have been managed.
questions.rationale: Module 10 specifies timing for shock assessment after MARCH priorities are addressed.

questions.prompt: How often does the module recommend checking a casualty for AVPU during reassessment?
questions.rationale: Module 10 states to check every 15 minutes for AVPU.

questions.prompt: If a casualty becomes unconscious OR their breathing rate drops below two respirations every 15 seconds, insert an NPA.
questions.rationale: Module 10 provides this reassessment trigger for NPA insertion.

questions.prompt: Fluids by mouth are permissible if the casualty is conscious and can swallow.
questions.rationale: Module 10 explicitly allows oral fluids if conscious and able to swallow.

questions.prompt: Select ALL that apply: Shock management guidance includes:
options: Reassess the casualty frequently for onset of shock
Evacuate if medical help is not available
Ignore hypothermia risk in hot environments
questions.rationale: Module 10 includes recovery position, reassess frequently, and evacuate if needed; it warns hypothermia risk exists even in hot environments.

questions.prompt: SCENARIO: In TFC, bleeding appears controlled, airway is open, and respirations are managed. The casualty is now confused and you cannot feel a radial pulse. What does this combination most strongly indicate (per the module’s tactical indicators)?
options: Significant blood loss with likely hemorrhagic shock
questions.rationale: Module 10 states the best tactical indicators are decreased mental status (without head injury) and weak/absent radial pulse; together they indicate significant blood loss and shock.

modules.title: Principles and Application of Tactical Field Care
